head.title: Chrebet and Elias Fined After Guilty Pleas

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey
Top/News/Sports/Pro Football/National Football League/New York Jets

hedline.hl1: Chrebet and Elias Fined After Guilty Pleas

abstract.p: New York Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet and Keith Elias, running back formerly with New York Giants and Indianapolis Colts, are each fined $230 after pleading guilty to a nuisance violation stemming from disturbance outside a Seaside Heights, NJ, bar on Feb 6 (S)

block.p: Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet and Keith Elias, a running back formerly with the Giants and the Indianapolis Colts, were each fined $230 yesterday after pleading guilty to a nuisance violation stemming from a disturbance outside a Seaside Heights, N.J., bar on Feb. 6.

Chrebet had been arrested and charged with disorderly conduct outside the Bamboo Bar, and Elias, who is now a free agent, had been arrested and charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest. Two of Elias's brothers were also arrested.

Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet and Keith Elias, a running back formerly with the Giants and the Indianapolis Colts, were each fined $230 yesterday after pleading guilty to a nuisance violation stemming from a disturbance outside a Seaside Heights, N.J., bar on Feb. 6.

Chrebet had been arrested and charged with disorderly conduct outside the Bamboo Bar, and Elias, who is now a free agent, had been arrested and charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest. Two of Elias's brothers were also arrested.

In court yesterday, Chrebet, Elias and his brothers pleaded guilty to a lesser offense of violating the town's public-nuisance ordinance, a routine procedure, according to the deputy court administrator, Mary Jo Pisciotta.
Chrebet did not appear in court, but was represented by his lawyer, Arthur B. Weiss.
''It was so insignificant that he didn't even have to appear in court,'' Weiss told The Associated Press, adding that Chrebet opted to plead guilty to avoid the publicity of a trial.
The three Elias brothers did appear in court. Brian and Gregory Elias were also fined $230 for violating the same local ordinance.
A spokesman for the National Football League said the league had been monitoring the case since the arrests and that yesterday's pleas would be reviewed under the league's personal-conduct policy.

Kim Pascarella, the municipal prosecutor, said the incident began with a disagreement inside the bar that did not involve the four, but it spilled outside onto a sidewalk, where the four were arrested.
Detective Sgt. David Szalkowski of Seaside Heights said the incident was a misunderstanding.
''I think it got blown out of proportion,'' Szalkowski told The Associated Press.
''If they were going around shoving people, especially with their celebrity status, the victims would have come forward, if any existed.''
